_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Pull stations at Engine Room Entrances
_prev_prog_3.Description: The refrigeration process has been evaluated to ensure that the system which was installed before current codes were applicable, is safe to operate and/or in compliance with ASHRAE standards and ANSI/IIAR 2-1999.  A Process Hazard Analysis review and update was conducted with direction from Safety Compliance Services.  Hazards were identified and abatement activities initiated.  Monitoring systems, operating procedures, engineering controls and safe work practices were developed, updated and implemented in order to protect employees, the community and the environment from the consequences of an accidental release of product or failure of vessels or components.  Ammonia detectors with automatic shutdown systems have been installed along with pull down alarms at all Engine Room entrances.  In addition, visual alarms, hourly/daily inspections, extensive training, maintenance and safe work procedures have been implemented/installed to maintain the safe operation of this process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Ambassador Services, Inc.in Cape Canaveral, FL is committed to protecting its employees, the surrounding community and the environment from an accidental release of the anhydrous ammonia.   Ammonia is used in the refrigeration system.  The release prevention program addresses issues as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance and training to ensure that releases do not occur.  Frequent inspections, regular maintenance, process monitors, rigorous supervised on-the-job training and 24 hour surveillance of the process reduce the likelihood and severity of an accidental release.  If a release does occur, however, employees are trained to contain the spill from a safe distance and implement notification procedures.  The emergency shutdown will be automatic with our monitoring/detection system.  There are manual emergency pull shut down alarms installed at the entrance to all engine rooms.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the Cape Canaveral Fire and Rescue Services located within minutes of the facility. 

2.    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The facility is a cold and dry storage warehouse.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as cooling material in a closed system.  The maximum intended inventory is 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia within the system.  It is the only regulated substance at the site that equals or exceeds the threshold quantity.  Due to the amount of product and the location of public receptors, the facility is covered as a Level 3 facility under EPA's regulation 40 CFR-69, the Risk Management Program (RMP).  The facility is also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119.  

3.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

This facility has developed all prevention program elements based on both the Federal EPA's Accident Release (RMP) requirements set forth in 40

CFR Part 68 and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR-1910-119. A brief discussion of each element follows: 

Process Safety Information - 



The facility has process safety information related to the designed and constructed.  The refrigeration system is built and operated in accordance with codes and standards.  The system has consistently performed without a major releases establishing a history of safe operation.  Drawings and written information specific to the process are maintained on site.  

Process Hazard Analyses - 

A PHA was conducted, deficiencies identified and corrections scheduled and/or implemented.  All PHAs are reviewed before re-submission and were reviewed and updated this year (August 1, 2019) 

Operating Procedures - 

SOPs, SMPs, PMPs were developed and implemented for all activities relating to the process and prepared in accordance with OSHA and EPA guidelines.  They are reviewed at least annually and revised as necessary to remain consistent with the process.  

Training - 

Employees initially undergo an extensive 6-month apprenticeship with specific training, both classroom and on the job, in all phases of the process.  Refresher training is provided every 3 years or more frequently if necessary.  All process employees are trained to HazWoper Technician Level emergency response on an annual basis. 

Mechanical Integrity - 

An extensive maintenance program for all components has been implemented.  Thorough inspections, (hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, etc.) are performed and deviations or deficiencies corrected immediately.  Standard Maintenance Procedures (SMPs) and Preventative Maintenance Procedures (PMPs) have been written for all maintenance and inspection activities and are reviewed annually to ensure that they are current. 

Management of Change - 

Our management of change procedure is in place, however, during the past five years, work performed on the system has only been "replacement in kind". 

Pre-Startup

Reviews - 

Are conducted any time the ammonia refrigeration system or its components are opened for repairs, tie-ins or modifications.  A checklist has been developed and is used to ensure safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. 

Compliance Audits - 

Audits are conducted every 3 years and corrective actions required as a result of the audits implemented immediately.  The latest inspection was conducted by FL DEM and separately a consultant, D.E.I., Inc. in July 2018. 

Incident Investigation - 

There is a program in place to promptly investigate any incident that resulted in, or had the potential for, an accidental release of ammonia.  The program is designed to identify root causes and indicate preventative measures to prevent a re-occurrence.  The reports are maintained on file for the life of the process.

Employee Participation - 

Every employee involved in the process has participated in all phases of the establishment of the Risk Management Program.  They have also participated in the audits and PHAs as well.  Each employee is dedicated to the prevention of product releases and subsequent potential injuries to themselves, their coworkers, the surrounding community and the environment. 

Contractors - 

A procedure for reviewing the safety performance and past safety history of any contractor hired to work on or with the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system has been developed and will be followed.  The policy includes an obligation to inform the contractor of the hazards they and their workers will be exposed to as well as emergency response procedures.  An annual performance evaluation system to ensure that the Contractor adheres to the company safety and health policies is contained within the procedures.

4.    The Five-year Accident History - 

There have been no reportable accident in the past 5 years. 

5.    The Emergency Response Program - 

In the event of a discharge, employees would control the leak from a safe distance and perform

only those activities supporting outside emergency response personnel that would be outside the "danger zone".  The Cape Canaveral Fire and Rescue would be contacted immediately and provide spill response.  Evacuation procedures are in place and would be initiated if necessary.  The plan has been coordinated carefully with the Cape Canaveral Fire and Rescue.  Also, have removal of ammonia vapors after a spill procedures.  

6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety - 

The facility and all employees involved in the process continue to inspect and examine all components of the system to identify areas where improvements can be made.  All deficiencies noted on audits, inspections and daily observations are corrected and recommendations based on PHAs implemented immediately.
